data.title: Extension-specific Workbench Settings
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.12.2
- OS Version: 10.12.4

User story: As a developer, I would like to have workbench styles based on file type. As someone who writes both Markdown files and JS in the same project, having the ability to have different workbench settings (i.e. theme, background color, etc.) based on file type would help.

data.title: Impossible to tell source of some messages; need some kind of blame indicator
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.12.2 (19222cdc84ce72202478ba1cec5cb557b71163de, 2017-05-10T13:20:36.315Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.14393
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|html-snippets|abusaidm|0.1.0|
|vscode-color|anseki|0.4.1|
|unique-lines|bibhasdn|1.0.0|
|npm-intellisense|christian-kohler|1.3.0|
|regex|chrmarti|0.1.0|
|vscode-eslint|dbaeumer|1.2.11|
|python|donjayamanne|0.6.4|
|xml|DotJoshJohnson|1.7.0|
|EditorConfig|EditorConfig|0.9.3|
|tslint|eg2|0.15.0|
|vscode-npm-script|eg2|0.1.9|
|json2ts|GregorBiswanger|0.0.6|
|live-html-previewer|hdg|0.0.1|
|beautify|HookyQR|1.1.1|
|vscode-JS-CSS-HTML-formatter|lonefy|0.2.3|
|MagicPython|magicstack|1.0.10|
|mssql|ms-mssql|1.0.0|
|cpptools|ms-vscode|0.11.2|
|csharp|ms-vscode|1.10.0|
|PowerShell|ms-vscode|1.2.0|
|vs-keybindings|ms-vscode|0.1.3|
|debugger-for-chrome|msjsdiag|3.1.2|
|smartpaste|rebornix|0.0.3|
|vscode-icons|robertohuertasm|7.8.1|
|preview-vscode|searKing|1.1.5|
|code-settings-sync|Shan|2.8.1|
|vba|spences10|1.0.17|
|vba-snippets|spences10|1.0.1|
|vscode-vba-icons|spences10|1.0.2|
|vscode-gulp|tanato|0.0.4|
|python|tht13|0.2.3|
|vscode-typings|typings|0.0.5|
|lorem-ipsum|Tyriar|1.0.0|
|bootstrap-3-snippets|wcwhitehead|0.0.9|
|JavaScriptSnippets|xabikos|1.4.0|
|Material-theme|zhuangtongfa|2.8.1|
|html-css-class-completion|Zignd|1.2.1|;


---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Have an extension that displays a message without identifying itself. In my case, I think it might be the vscode-eslint extension? I'm not sure. That's the whole point of reporting this issue.

Here's an example of what I mean:
![screenshot](https://i.stack.imgur.com/LThSY.png)

Notice that nothing in the error message says anything about which extension is reporting the error. That it doesn't even tell me which file is the problem is another issue that I will bring up with the extension author. However, I'd like to see VSCode provide some way to determine the source of a message that isn't thoughtful enough to identify its owner.

data.title: The value of TextDocument.isClosed is incorrect when a text document is closed
Tooltips available for SCM diff decorations

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
This pull request is intended to complete feature request #25849.  The image below illustrates this feature (with my cheapo Paint cursor):

![25849_sm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/459665/26741946/7da345ba-47a9-11e7-803d-57342254f521.jpg)

There are two caveats.  The first, @joaomoreno recommended to have this new tooltip property in the `SourceControlResourceThemableDecorations` interface of the API.  I found that to be nested one level too deep, so instead I created the property in the `SourceControlResourceDecorations`.

The second, I'm unsure if I'm breaking any project protocol by calling the `localize()` the way it is in `git/src/model.ts`.  Any key value will do?

Let me know if anything else is needed!

data.title: Ignored files still being watched/processed
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.13.0-insider
- OS Version: macOS 10.12.5

> Info: Cannot read config file: /Users/iradchenko/workspace/mldp/src/MLDP.WebApp/tmp/broccoli_persistent_filterbabelbabel_mldp-output_path-jl0jlxN3.tmp/mldp/tests/.eslintrc.js Error: define is not defined

My config is like so:

```json
{
  "editor.tabSize": 2,
  "search.exclude": {
    "**/.git": true,
    "**/node_modules": true,
    "**/bower_components": true,
    "**/tmp": true,
    "**/dist": true,
    "**/.vscode/chrome": true,
    "**/wwwroot": true
  },
  "files.watcherExclude": {
    "**/.git/objects/**": true,
    "**/.git/subtree-cache/**": true,
    "**/tmp/**": true,
    "**/bower_components/**": true,
    "**/node_modules/**": true,
    "**/typings/**": true,
    "**/wwwroot/**": true
  },
  "workbench.colorTheme": "Ayu Mirage",
  "workbench.iconTheme": "material-icon-theme",
  "dart.debugSdkLibraries": false,
  "dart.debugExternalLibraries": false,
  "vim.disableAnnoyingNeovimMessage": true
}
```

Notice `"**/tmp/**": true,` in `files.watcherExclude`. I'd expect this to be enough to prevent VSCode to stop going through the `tmp/**` files (of which there are many).

data.title: Context for "scm/resourceState/context" when clauses.
Find/Replace Usability: Enter and Ctrl+Enter shortcuts
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.12.2
- OS Version: Windows 10

In addition to `editor.action.replaceAll` and `editor.action.replaceOne`, there exists other shortcuts that work in the Find and Replace dialog:
 - <kbd>CTRL</kbd>+<kbd>ENTER</kbd> is a shortcut for `editor.action.replaceAll`
 - <kbd>ENTER</kbd> is similar to `editor.action.replaceOne`

These are amazingly helpful.  A lot easier than using the defaults (<kbd>CTRL</kbd>+<kbd>ALT</kbd>+<kbd>ENTER</kbd> and <kbd>CTRL</kbd>+<kbd>SHIFT</kbd>+<kbd>1</kbd> respectively)

Unfortunately, these shortcuts only work when the Replace text box has focus, not the Find text box.

Is it possible to wire these up to the Find text box so that no matter which input you fill in last, you can execute the a replaceAll or replaceOne as quickly as possible?

FYI: I can override the `editor.action.replaceAll` shortcut with <kbd>CTRL</kbd>+<kbd>ENTER</kbd>, and that gets me halfway there, but attempting to override `editor.action.replaceOne` with <kbd>ENTER</kbd> obviously isn't going to work.  Interestingly enough, it does let me do it, and it does work (with major side effects obviously), but it executes replaceOne twice when the Replace text box has focus, I assume because of the configurable shortcut and the internal shortcut.

data.title: Find/Replace Usability: Tabbing between fields should select all text
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.12.2
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. With an editor tab in focus, make a selection of a few characters and press CTRL+H to open the find/replace dialog.
2. If the Replace text box (the second one) is empty, enter some text, press escape, and repeat step 1.
3. You'll notice that the text in the Replace text box is selected.  This allows the user to quickly type something new without worrying about the selection or cursor position.
4. Press shift tab to move focus to the Find text box (the first one).  The cursor, by default, appears at the end of the text box.

Ideally all of the text in the Find text box would be selected allowing the user to quickly type over it.  The current implementation appears to preserve the selection and cursor position, which can be jarring because it's inconsistent (unless you're keeping track of the cursor position in your head, which seems unlikely).

The behavior I'm describing and requesting here is the same behavior in Visual Studio as well as Notepad and many other applications in Windows.  I can't speak for OSX, but as far as usability goes, selecting the text instead of preserving the selection seems to be more desirable.

data.title: Symbol tooltips can't handle at-sign inside markdown block
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.12.2
- OS Version: Windows 10

**Steps to Reproduce:**

1. Open a TS-file and add/locate a comment block for any class/function/interface
2. Inside the block, add a markdown code block (\`\`\`) that contains `@` at the beginning of a row
3. Hover over the declaration, and it's tooltip description will terminate at the start of the `@` sign

![vscode-ts-markdown-hover](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8770194/26735380/11613c68-47c2-11e7-9339-3efb104e853e.gif)

**Minimum code for reproducing the issue:**
```typescript
/**
 * ```
 * @Hello
 * ```
 */
class Demo {}
```
The above should show just ``` if you hover over `Demo`.

Decorators are fairly common inside TS/JS code at the moment. This issue pops up a lot inside `@angular/*` packages, but should be fairly common for any other Typescript projects too.

data.title: Show build-in extensions in extension list
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.12.2
- OS Version: Windows 10

To give a user more context on what a build in extension does, it could be useful to show build in extension in the extension view. In this page an user can disable an extension. For example, as mentioned in #27878, not everyone wants to use Emmet. It is weird to disable build in extensions trough settings and user installed extensions trough the extension view.
Because an user can read a description on the usage of an extension, they may found out why certain behaviour is implemented, for example tab-to-expand with Emmet. This could lead to more knowledge and less annoyances. 

Another thing this could potentially fix is build in extension upgrade-ability. When there are bugs in a language, not the whole product has to reinstall with the fix for the extension, but a push through the extension market is enough, a bit like build in apps in Windows and Android go trough the store.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open the extension view
2. No build in extensions are shown

data.title: Absolute imports don't work in JavaScript in a mixed TS + JS project
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.12.2
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a mix JS and TS project
2. Use an absolute import in a JavaScript file (.js extension, to be 100% clear), like 

`import {FilterBar, SearchVm, sortByCaptions, sortDateCaptions} from 'tasks/list/searchVm';`

The existence of a tsconfig file makes the typing / intellisense not work for this import.  I've confirmed that deleting the tsconfig.json file (temporarily) causes everything to work correctly.  I thought maybe having a tsconfig could be a substitute for a jsconfig, so I also tried deleting jsconfig.json, but that didn't work either.

---

Making the import relative, ie 

`import {FilterBar, SearchVm, sortByCaptions, sortDateCaptions} from '../searchVm';`

also fixes this, and causes correct type inferences / intellisense to work fine, so it does seem VS Code can't find my baseUrl setting in jsconfig.json when there's also a tsconfig.json file.

---

Is there some setting I need so my jsonfig.json file be respected, if there's also a tsconfig.json file?

For completeness, this is my tsconfig file

```
{
    "compilerOptions": {
        "target": "esnext",
        "baseUrl": "./src",
        "jsx": "react",
        "allowSyntheticDefaultImports": true,
        "allowUnreachableCode": true,
        "allowJs": true,
        "moduleResolution": "node",
        "module": "es2015",
        "experimentalDecorators": true,
        "lib": ["es2015", "dom"],
        "typeRoots" : ["./typings/modules", "./node_modules/@types"]
    },
    "include": [
        "./src/**/*.ts",
        "./src/**/*.tsx"
    ]
}
```

and this is my jsconfig file (some properties may not be needed - prior to opening this case I copied pretty much all of the tsconfig config in there, but since the file's not in git I'm not sure what was there before)

```
{
    "compilerOptions": { 
        "target": "esnext",
        "baseUrl": "./src",
        "jsx": "react",
        "allowSyntheticDefaultImports": true,
        "allowUnreachableCode": true,
        "module": "es2015",
        "experimentalDecorators": true,
        "lib": ["es2015", "dom"]
    },
    "include": [
        "./src/**/*.js",
        "./src/**/*.jsx"
    ],
    "exclude": [
        "./dist/**/*"
    ]
}
```

data.title: Specifying an alternate dotfile (rcs) for zsh in integrated terminal causes failure to launch terminal.
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->
I use zsh as my shell and in my zshrc I have it automatically attach to a tmux session if it exists or create a new one if it doesn't. This causes the terminal to connect to my main tmux session whenever I open it, causing issues with my tmux session in my iTerm2 window. This becomes a problem because I spend 90% of my working day in a terminal, but would like the convenience of being able to run quick commands from the integrated terminal. 

zsh has a --rcs option that you can use to specify an alternate config/dotfile to start it up, which I would like to use because I have a lot of things being added to my path due to work restrictions requiring Homebrew to be installed in my home directory. I also use zsh-syntax-highlighting and some other plugins in zsh which I do not want to be without.


- VSCode Version: 1.12.2
- OS Version: macOS Sierra 10.12.5

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Have zsh and oh-my-zsh installed and set as your shell.
2. Add the line ```"terminal.integrated.shellArgs.osx": ["--rcs", "/path/to/alternate/doftile"]``` to your settings.json
3. Launch new integrated terminal.

Expected Behavior: New integrated terminal launches with alternate dotfile as your default able to proceed as normal.
Actual Behavior: Terminal dies immediately.

data.title: Guides extension has detected that you are using "editor.renderIndentGuides" settings. Guides will now disable all indentation guides by override the style to "none".
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.13.0-insider (af2752dad442341000b0bf95861b91ecd8263ca0, 2017-06-02T05:14:12.971Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.15063
- Extensions: the listing length exceeds browsers' URL characters limit
---

I do not have "editor.renderIndentGuides" set but recently (3 or 4 days ago?) after updating to the latest Insider Preview I started seeing this every time my editor is restarted or I open VS Code. Is there any way to suppress this message?
